message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Evolutionary dynamics of higher-order interactions in social networks
Paper Abstract: We live and cooperate in networks. However, links in networks only allow for pairwise interactions, thus making the framework suitable for dyadic games, but not for games that are played in larger groups. Here, we study the evolutionary dynamics of a public goods game in social systems with higher-order interactions. First, we show that the game on uniform hypergraphs corresponds to the replicator dynamics in the well-mixed limit, providing a formal theoretical foundation to study cooperation in networked groups. Second, we unveil how the presence of hubs and the coexistence of interactions in groups of different sizes affects the evolution of cooperation. Finally, we apply the proposed framework to extract the actual dependence of the synergy factor on the size of a group from real-world collaboration data in science and technology. Our work provides a way to implement informed actions to boost cooperation in social groups.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Hypergraph

A hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices.(no content)In contrast, in an ordinary graph, an edge connects exactly two vertices.

### Key Characteristics

A hypergraph is a pair (V, E), where V is a set of vertices and E is a set of subsets of V called hyperedges. Each hyperedge may contain one or more vertices.

### Applications

Undirected hypergraphs are useful in modelling such things as satisfiability problems, databases, machine learning, and Steiner tree problems. They have been extensively used in machine learning tasks as the data model and classifier regularization. The applications include recommender system (communities as hyperedges), image retrieval (correlations as hyperedges), and bioinformatics (biochemical interactions as hyperedges).

### Related Concepts

Some specialized types of hypergraphs include:
- A hypergraph whose edges all have size k is called k-uniform. (A 2-uniform hypergraph is a graph).
- A matching in a hypergraph is a set of hyperedges, in which every two hyperedges are disjoint. It is an extension of the notion of matching in a graph.

Web search results for query: "Evolutionary dynamics"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Eco-evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eco-evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Martin Nowak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Nowak"},{"title":"Evolutionary invasion analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_invasion_analysis"},{"title":"Red Queen hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Queen_hypothesis"},{"title":"Katsuhito Iwai - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuhito_Iwai"},{"title":"Brigitte Pakendorf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brigitte_Pakendorf"},{"title":"Evolutionary arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_arms_race"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what you need to know about evolutionary dynamics:

## Definition and Scope

Evolutionary dynamics is the study of the mathematical principles according to which biological organisms as well as cultural ideas evolve and evolved.(no content)This is mostly achieved through the mathematical discipline of population genetics, along with evolutionary game theory.

## Key Approaches

**Evolutionary Game Theory**: Evolutionary game theory differs from classical game theory in focusing more on the dynamics of strategy change, which is influenced by the frequency of the competing strategies in the population.(no content)The common way to study the evolutionary dynamics in games is through replicator equations, which show the growth rate of the proportion of organisms using a certain strategy and that rate is equal to the difference between the average payoff of that strategy and the average payoff of the population as a whole.

**Adaptive Dynamics**: Evolutionary invasion analysis, also known as adaptive dynamics, is a set of mathematical modeling techniques that use differential equations to study the long-term evolution of traits in asexually and sexually reproducing populations.

## Related Concepts

Eco-evolutionary dynamics refers to the reciprocal effects that ecology and evolution have on each other. Additionally, an evolutionary arms race is an ongoing struggle between competing sets of co-evolving genes, phenotypic and behavioral traits that develop escalating adaptations and counter-adaptations against each other.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Replicator equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_equation"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Chicken (game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicken_(game)"},{"title":"Replicator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator"},{"title":"Replicator (cellular automaton) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(cellular_automaton)"},{"title":"Replicator (United States military) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(United_States_military)"},{"title":"Self-replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replication"},{"title":"Replicator (Star Trek) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(Star_Trek)"},{"title":"DNA replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_replication"},{"title":"Self-replicating machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replicating_machine"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about **replicator dynamics**:

## Overview

In mathematics, the replicator equation is a type of dynamical system used in evolutionary game theory to model how the frequency of strategies in a population changes over time.

## Basic Principles

Replicator dynamics is a simple model of strategy change commonly used in evolutionary game theory. In this model, a strategy which does better than the average increases in frequency at the expense of strategies that do worse than the average.

More specifically, the growth rate of the proportion of organisms using a certain strategy equals the difference between the average payoff of that strategy and the average payoff of the population as a whole.

## Characteristics

It is a deterministic, monotone, non-linear, and non-innovative dynamic that captures the principle of natural selection. Additionally, the replicator dynamics models heredity but not mutation, and assumes asexual reproduction for the sake of simplicity.

## Applications

Replicator dynamics have been widely applied in fields such as biology (to study evolution and population dynamics), economics (to analyze bounded rationality and strategy evolution), and machine learning (particularly in multi-agent systems and reinforcement learning).

Links: [{"title":"Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Collective action problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action_problem"},{"title":"Strong reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_reciprocity"},{"title":"CC–PP game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CC–PP_game"},{"title":"Talk:Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Public good - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_good"},{"title":"Samuelson condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuelson_condition"},{"title":"Lindahl tax - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindahl_tax"},{"title":"Dictator game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dictator_game"},{"title":"Digital public goods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_public_goods"}]

Here are the search results for "Public goods game":

## Overview

The public goods game is a standard of experimental economics.(no content)In the basic game, subjects secretly choose how many of their private tokens to put into a public pot.

## How It Works

Each participant is given some amount of money. They are then allowed to contribute any of their allocation to a common pool. The common pool is then multiplied by some amount greater than one, then evenly redistributed to each participant, regardless of how much they contributed.

## Theoretical vs. Actual Behavior

In this game, for anyone trying to maximize their payoff, the rational nash equilibrium strategy is to not contribute anything. However, real-world behavior differs significantly from this prediction. In a 2001 study, Fischbacher observed average contributions of 33.5%.(no content)The actual levels of contribution found varies widely (anywhere from 0% to 100% of initial endowment can be chipped in).

## Applications

Public goods games are valuable in understanding the role of incentives in an individual's behaviours. Here are the search results for "Public goods game":

## Overview

The public goods game is a standard of experimental economics.(no content)In the basic game, subjects secretly choose how many of their private tokens to put into a public pot.

## How It Works

Each participant is given some amount of money. They are then allowed to contribute any of their allocation to a common pool. The common pool is then multiplied by some amount greater than one, then evenly redistributed to each participant, regardless of how much they contributed.

## Theoretical vs. Actual Behavior

In this game, for anyone trying to maximize their payoff, the rational nash equilibrium strategy is to not contribute anything. However, real-world behavior differs significantly from this prediction. In a 2001 study, Fischbacher observed average contributions of 33.5%.(no content)The actual levels of contribution found varies widely (anywhere from 0% to 100% of initial endowment can be chipped in).

## Applications

Public goods games are valuable in understanding the role of incentives in an individual's behaviours. They arise from behavioural economics and have broad applications to societal challenges.(no content)Examples of applications include environmental policy, legal and justice issues and workplace and organisational structures.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Cooperation evolution game theory"

Links: [{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"The Complexity of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Complexity_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Reciprocity (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism_in_humans"},{"title":"Tit for tat - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tit_for_tat"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"}]

Here are the search results for cooperation and evolution in game theory:

## Overview

Evolutionary game theory provides a solution to the problem of altruism through application to the prisoner's dilemma game, which tests the payoffs of cooperating versus defecting, making it the most studied game in all of game theory.

## Key Theoretical Foundations

Reciprocity in evolutionary biology refers to mechanisms whereby the evolution of cooperative or altruistic behavior may be favored by the probability of future mutual interactions. There are two main types of reciprocity:

**Direct Reciprocity:** Direct reciprocity was proposed by Robert Trivers as a mechanism for the evolution of cooperation, where repeated encounters between the same two players can favor mutual cooperation even if each player has short-term incentive to defect.

**Indirect Reciprocity:** Reputation allows evolution of cooperation by indirect reciprocity, with natural selection favoring strategies that base the decision to help on the recipient's reputation.

## The Tit-for-Tat Strategy

The winning strategy from Axelrod's tournaments was "tit for tat," which cooperates on the first move and subsequently echoes what the other player did on the previous move.(no content)Success in evolutionary games correlated with being nice (cooperating, never being first to defect) and being provocable (returning defection for defection, cooperation for cooperation).

## Applications and Extensions

Research on the evolution of cooperation has expanded to cover prosocial behavior generally, and in religion, other mechanisms for generating cooperation, the iterated prisoner's dilemma under different conditions, and other games such as the Public Goods and Ultimatum games to explore notions of fairness.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"The Social Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Network"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Distributed social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_social_network"},{"title":"Social Networks (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Networks_(journal)"},{"title":"The Social Reckoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Reckoning"},{"title":"Threads (social network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threads_(social_network)"}]

I've completed the web search for "Social network" and found comprehensive information across multiple dimensions:

## General Definition

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Social Networking Services

A social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)These are websites that facilitate the building of a network of contacts in order to exchange various types of content online.

## Historical Development

Social media started in the mid-1990s with the invention of platforms like GeoCities, Classmates.com, and SixDegrees.com, with SixDegrees being unique as it was the first online service designed for people to connect using their actual names instead of anonymously.(no content)In 2005, MySpace had more pageviews than Google.(no content)In the early 2000s, social media platforms gained widespread popularity with BlackPlanet (1999) preceding Friendster and Myspace, followed by Facebook, YouTube, and Twitter.

## Current Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

The search results also covered social network analysis (the academic study of network relationships), the film "The Social Network," and emerging platforms like Threads.
